descriptionSet.description: A white woman with short red hair is depicted wearing a fur coat baring her left shoulder. She is wearing a glittering bracelet, a ring and earrings.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: PEARS The Jewel of Soaps
description-en: A white woman with short red hair is depicted wearing a fur coat baring her left shoulder. She is wearing a glittering bracelet, a ring and earrings. (gs/tb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Children were useful for advertising because of the association suggested by their skin ("like babies"). This association could later be transposed onto the figure of grown women as was the case with Pears that marketed a gentle transparent soap made of glycerin. The company ran beauty contests for little children and many "Miss Pears" would later become actresses or models. The Pears advertisement that we see features this possibility, not just of beauty but glamour and wealth judging from her expensive fur coat, jewelry and fashionable hairstyle. (Sabeena Gadihoke)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Pears, today produced by Unilever, was founded by the barber Andrew Pears in 1789. Back then there was no luxurious soap for the rich on the market. Pears aimed at closing this gap and produced a new recipe for soap bars which were more gentle to the skin (see http://www.beauty-soap-and-bubbles.com/pears-soap.html). According to Anne McClintock soaps like Pears played a decisive role in colonialsm as its advertising carried a powerful racial ideology she refers to as "commodity racism". Many soap advertising images in the colonial period conveyed the message that soap is the means to bring civilization. For instance, one ad from 1899 argued that "The first step toward lightening THE WHITE MAN'S BURDEN is through teaching the virtues of cleanliness. PEARS' SOAP is a potent fact in brightening the dark corners of the earth as civilization advances." (citation taken from http://science.jrank.org/pages/8820/Consumerism-SOAP.html#ixzz1Vf1A9MCv). Thus, soap was one of the major symbolic carriers of whiteness and imperialism and Victorian notions of gender. (la)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Part of the Times of India Yearbook 1937 (la)
